intro: Vicia latibracteolata var. acerosa, commonly known as the broad-bract vetch, is a perennial legume native to the Mediterranean region. It features slender, erect stems that can grow up to 1 meter in height, often branching towards the upper portion. The leaves are pinnate, with 5–9 pairs of oval to ovate leaflets, and the plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in racemose inflorescences. Its pods are cylindrical, hairy, and contain several elliptical seeds. This species is known for its adaptability to various soil types and its role in nitrogen fixation due to its symbiotic relationship with rhizobia.
